data.title: RAG | definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary
data.snippet:
See more results »

### RAG noun (LEVELS)

(/us/help/codes.html)   business, education   UK specialized

abbreviation for Red Amber Green: a system for judging the success or progress of something such as a project or task, or a particular level according to this system, with "green" meaning that something is going well, "amber" that there may be some problems, and "red" that there are serious problems:

The management team relies heavily on RAG to quickly assess the health of all ongoing projects.

The project manager decided to move the overall RAG from amber to red.

RAG status To assist with monitoring performance, each of the indicators is allocated a RAG status.

More examplesFewer examples [...] rag on someone

RAG

noun

us
/ræɡ/ uk
/ræɡ/

### RAG noun (COMPUTING)

(/us/help/codes.html)   computing   specialized

abbreviation for retrieval-augmented generation: a method that helps AI language models give better answers by first looking up useful information in various relevant sources (= that can supply information suitable for a particular purpose) and then using that information to produce a more accurate answer:

RAG allows LLMs to build on a specialized body of knowledge to answer questions in more accurate ways.

Through RAG, companies can have AI models draw from the most up-to-date internal information.

More examplesFewer examples [...] rag

noun (/us/help/codes.html)

us
/ræɡ/

Add to word list Add to word list

a piece of usually old, torn cloth:

I use these rags for cleaning.

They were dressed in rags (= in old, torn pieces of clothing).

(Definition of rag from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary © Cambridge University Press)

## Examples of rag

rag

The injuries come from hitting heads on the ceiling or being thrown around in the aisle like a rag doll. 

From CNN

Showy rejections of social norms -- rags worn, street corners stood upon, shouts directed at passersby -- complement refusals to accept the political or philosophical status quo. 

From NPR

In it was a stove in many pieces held together with wire, a bedstead with rags for mattress and rags for covering. 

From Huffington Post

## rag

(ræg)

Word forms: plural, 3rd person singular present tense rags,  present participle ragging,  past tense, past participle ragged

1. variable noun

A rag is a piece of old cloth which you can use to clean or wipe things.

He was wiping his hands on an oily rag.

Synonyms: cloth, piece of cloth   More Synonyms of rag

2. plural noun

Rags are old torn clothes.

There were men, women, and small children, some dressed in rags.

3. countable noun

People refer to a newspaper as a rag when they have a poor opinion of it. [...] informal

transitive verb

1. 

to scold

2. (often fol. by  on) 

to subject to a teasing, esp. in an intense or prolonged way

Some of the boys were ragging on him about his haircut

3. Brit

to torment with jokes; play crude practical jokes on

noun

4. Brit

an act of ragging

data.title: What is RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation)? - IBM
data.snippet:
# What is retrieval augmented generation (RAG)?

## What is retrieval augmented generation (RAG)?

Retrieval augmented generation, or RAG, is an architecture for optimizing the performance of an artificial intelligence (AI) model by connecting it with external knowledge bases. RAG helps large language models (LLMs) deliver more relevant responses at a higher quality.

Generative AI (gen AI) models are trained on large datasets and refer to this information to generate outputs. However, training datasets are finite and limited to the information the AI developer can access—public domain works, internet articles, social media content and other publicly accessible data.
